column2: As he was passing the house of Boo'koo, the big rat, that worthy gentleman invited him in.

column2: I would like you to come and help me to eat it."

column2: In the midst of the feast, who should appear at the foot of the tree but Sim'ba, the lion?

column2: Looking up, and seeing them eating, he asked, "Who are you?"

column2: Speak, I tell you!"

column2: This made Bookoo so scared that he blurted out, "It's only us!"

column2: Upon this the hare said to him: "You just wrap me up in this straw, call to the lion to keep out of the way, and then throw me down.

column2: After waiting a minute or two, Simba roared out, "Well, come down, I say!" and, there being no help for it, the big rat came down.
column3: After waiting a minute or two, Simba roared out, "Well, come down, I say!" and, there being no help for it, the big rat came down.

column2: As soon as he was within reach, the lion caught hold of him, and asked, "Who was up there with you?"
column3: As soon as he was within reach, the lion caught hold of him, and asked, "Who was up there with you?"

column2: Didn't you see him when I threw him down?"
column3: Didn't you see him when I threw him down?"

column2: Of course I didn't see him, replied the lion, in an incredulous tone, and, without wasting further time, he ate the big rat, and then searched around for the hare, but could not find him.
column3: Of course I didn't see him, replied the lion, in an incredulous tone, and, without wasting further time, he ate the big rat, and then searched around for the hare, but could not find him.

column2: Whose honey? inquired Kobay, cautiously.

column2: Just then Mr. Simba, who owned the honey, came out again, and, looking up, inquired, "Who are you, up there?"

column2: You told me this honey was yours; am I right in suspecting that it belongs to Simba?"

column2: So, when the lion asked again, "Who are you?" he answered, "It's only us." The lion said, "Come down, then;" and the tortoise answered, "We're coming."

column2: So the lion, being deceived, took him by the tail and whirled him around, but just as he was going to knock him on the ground he slipped out of his grasp and ran away, and Simba had the mortification of losing him again.
column3: So the lion, being deceived, took him by the tail and whirled him around, but just as he was going to knock him on the ground he slipped out of his grasp and ran away, and Simba had the mortification of losing him again.

column2: Angry and disappointed, he turned to the tree and called to Kobay, "You come down, too."
column3: Angry and disappointed, he turned to the tree and called to Kobay, "You come down, too."

column2: When the tortoise reached the ground, the lion said, "You're pretty hard; what can I do to make you eatable?"
column3: When the tortoise reached the ground, the lion said, "You're pretty hard; what can I do to make you eatable?"

column2: Oh, that's easy, laughed Kobay; "just put me in the mud and rub my back with your paw until my shell comes off."
column3: Oh, that's easy, laughed Kobay; "just put me in the mud and rub my back with your paw until my shell comes off."

column2: Immediately on hearing this, Simba carried Kobay to the water, placed him in the mud, and began, as he supposed, to rub his back; but the tortoise had slipped away, and the lion continued rubbing on a piece of rock until his paws were raw.

column2: When he glanced down at them he saw they were bleeding, and, realizing that he had again been outwitted, he said, "Well, the hare has done me to-day, but I'll go hunting now until I find him."

column2: Without loss of time the lion climbed the mountain, and soon arrived at the place indicated, only to find that there was no one at home.
